user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_short_params_str:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_short_params_str (const char *params_str, const char *next_param)
{
  if (0 == params_str[0])
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Unrecognised parameter: -\n");
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  do
  {
    enum PerfRepl_param_result param_res;
    param_res = process_short_param (params_str, next_param);
    if (PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR != param_res)
      return param_res;
  } while (0 != (++params_str)[0]);
  return PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (0 == params_str[0])
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17: the code fragment does not call any functions from <string.h>. The expression params_str[0] is a direct pointer dereference, so Rule 21.17 (which targets use of string.h functions) is not applicable. (Note: if params_str can be NULL, params_str[0] would be undefined behavior and would violate other MISRA rules, but not Rule 21.17.)
